text: colonel Rani Sultan has a short drive to
work he commands a sector of the front
line that runs along a busy densely
populated afternoon a couple of minutes
drive from the homes of several thousand
people is Joba one of the Capitals key
battlegrounds colonel Sultan and his men
are from the elite Republican Guard
hundreds of yards of military positions
have been carved out of the wreckage of
home the people who lived here escaped
with their memories and not much else
the colonel and his men say they are
Patriots fighting terrorists he rejects
accusations that the Syrian army targets
civilians the claim is that more
civilians are killed by the Syrian army
than by any other armed force here in
Syria that God casts be it is real order
decision this is all propaganda to slam
the reputation of the army it's all lies
we were brought up not to hurt peaceful
civilians we only kill people who see
with our own eyes holding a weapon close
by in a desert of blasted concrete our
rebel positions the colonel also said
that any civilians near armed rebels
must be supporting the army has attacked
repeatedly its soldiers have not been
able to force the rivers further from
the city center
the army has the heavier weapons they
pound the suburbs held by the rebels
when many civilians still live on the
rebel side this is what it's like to be
on the receiving end until the war ends
Syria will go on exporting violence and
refugees it shockwaves have rocked
Syria's neighbors now they're reaching
Europe this is why half Syria's
population has fled why millions of
parents want to get their children out
of harm's way
rebel fighters in the suburb of Duma
launch new attacks in the last few days
cutting a vital road
the war heads and flows but no side has
a decisive edge to get one the rebels
have dug tunnels under army positions
the Army's been blowing them up
the war has gone underground
the Syrian army dug into this 800 metre
tunnel which it says was part of a rebel
plan to attack the city center
if armed rebels broke through here they
could be in the heart of Damascus in
minutes it's one thing for people
politicians a very long way from here to
talk about the need for some kind of a
deal to end the war but viewed from the
battlefield that looks further away than
ever the dynamic of war has taken over
in Syria not politics or diplomacy
across Damascus you can hear the war
Syria is at the epicentre of
middle-eastern turmoil power cuts mean
that the nights are dark shows the
future Jeremy Bowen BBC news Damascus
